Authors:
Juan Enciso, Javier Felipe Tabima, Diego Mauricio
Riano-Pachon, Silvia Restrepo
Title:
Evolutionary history of the kingdom Protista using a
phylogenomics approach: New insights on the Chromalveolata
hypothesis
Keywords:
Eukaryotic phylogeny, Markovian Ortholog Clustering,
Supermatrix, Opisthokonta, Phylogenomics, Chromista, Stramenopila,
Alveolata.
Abstract:
The lack of organisation of discrete lineages in the
phylogeny and taxonomy of protists has precluded the understanding of
the groupÂ’s evolutionary history and trait comparison among their
members. We assume a phylogenomics approach to unravel the evolutionary
relationships inside eukaryotes and to propose phylogenetic hypotheses.
We used an automatic ortholog clustering (OrthoMCL)-based strategy to
recover clusters of orthologues from 86 eukaryotic species. A maximum
likelihood tree was inferred from the supermatrix including these groups
of orthologs. Overall, we obtained consistent inferences, but some
unexpected branching patterns were poorly supported. Despite the large
quantity of genes from the Opisthokonta groups, this clade appeared to
be polyphyletic. The Stramenopila and the Alveolata have been considered
sister taxa, but they were not grouped together in the present analysis.
The monophyly of the Excavata was recovered for all but three species
that were expected to group within it but were found scattered, most
likely because of long-branch attraction artefacts. A second dataset was
constructed after removing the fast-evolving/saturated sites, and a
Shimodaira-Hasegawa test was performed on three hypothetical trees to
verify whether our data allowed us to reject branching patterns that
were previously reported. The results of these tests suggested that the
competing tree topologies were not significantly better than our
recovered topologies; nevertheless, we found evidence that fails to
support the Chromalveolata hypothesis. Novel relationships were shown
inside the Opisthokonta, for two genera, Thecamonas trahens and
Capsaspora owczarzaki. Additionally, some controversial phylogenetic
positions among several eukaryotic groups were found using this
phylogenomics approach.
